pageContext.claim: “On January 23, I was told that there could be a virus coming in, but it was of no real import. In other words, it wasn't, oh, we have got to do something, we have got to do something. It was a brief conversation. And it was only on January 23.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump claims his oral intelligence briefing did not discuss the coronavirus until Jan. 23 and that the briefer did not highlight it as important. We have no idea if this is true, but from experience we have found that Trump is certainly often inaccurate in recounting conversations that might reflect poorly on him. But intelligence warnings about the coronavirus were contained in the President’s Daily Brief, a sensitive report that is produced before dawn each day and designed to call the president’s attention to the most significant global developments and security threats. "But the alarms appear to have failed to register with the president, who routinely skips reading the PDB and has at times shown little patience for even the oral summary he takes two or three times per week, according to the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified material," the Washington Post reported.
